dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Back in 2018, Trump's 25% tariff on steel really set the tone for this new era of protectionism.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Back in twenty eighteen, Trump's twenty five percent tariff on steel really set the tone for this new era of protectionism.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: During Donald Trumps presidency, the US imposed a 25% tariff on steel imports and a 10% tariff on imported aluminum.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and now we're seeing Biden take it even further with things like the Inflation Reduction Act—what, $430 billion?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and now we're seeing Biden take it even further with things like the Inflation Reduction Act-what, four hundred thirty dollars billion?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Biden administration, however, has gone even further, fully embracing industrial policy by enacting the $430 billion Inflation Reduction Act (IRA), which includes hundreds of billions of dollars in subsidies for green technologies and renewable energies, and the $280 billion CHIPS and Science Act, aimed at fostering a robust US semiconductor industry.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, and the CHIPS Act too, another $280 billion aimed at semiconductors. But it's not just about the money, right? It's how these policies are affecting global trade dynamics.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly, and the C H I P S Act too, another two hundred eighty dollars billion aimed at semiconductors. But it's not just about the money, right? It's how these policies are affecting global trade dynamics.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Biden administration, however, has gone even further, fully embracing industrial policy by enacting the $430 billion Inflation Reduction Act (IRA), which includes hundreds of billions of dollars in subsidies for green technologies and renewable energies, and the $280 billion CHIPS and Science Act, aimed at fostering a robust US semiconductor industry.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, for sure. Like, the EU is already responding with its own $47 billion semiconductor plan. It feels like a subsidy arms race.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, for sure. Like, the E U is already responding with its own forty seven dollars billion semiconductor plan. It feels like a subsidy arms race.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In response to Bidens industrial policies, for example, the European Union has recently greenlit a 43 billion ($47 billion) plan to bolster its semiconductor industry, while South Korea and Japan have also rolled out plans to subsidize domestic chip production.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And Morris Chung from TSMC pointed out that manufacturing chips in the US is 50% more expensive than in Taiwan. So these subsidies might not even cover the gap.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Morris Chung from T S M C pointed out that manufacturing chips in the U S is fifty percent more expensive than in Taiwan. So these subsidies might not even cover the gap.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Morris Chang, founder of the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, has recently estimated that chip manufacturing is 50% more expensive in the US than in Taiwan, where more than 90% of the worlds high-end chips are currently produced.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which makes you wonder, um, if all this spending is actually going to boost competitiveness or just inflate costs for everyone.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which makes you wonder, um, if all this spending is actually going to boost competitiveness or just inflate costs for everyone.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and Adam Posen at the Peterson Institute argues the real cost isn't just trade barriers—it's slower productivity growth in the long run.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and Adam Posen at the Peterson Institute argues the real cost isn't just trade barriers-it's slower productivity growth in the long run.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But as Adam Posen of the Peterson Institute for International Economics notes, the true price of economic decoupling is not so much trade barriers, bad as they are, but reduced productivity growth.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Plus, taxpayers are footing the bill for subsidies that might just get matched by other countries, nullifying any advantage.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Plus, taxpayers are footing the bill for subsidies that might just get matched by other countries, nullifying any advantage.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Depending on the size of retaliatory foreign subsidies, they may nullify some (if not all) of the competitive gains that the initial subsidy aimed to provide.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's like we're in a global subsidy war now, with no clear winners. Gina Raimondo even called the CHIPS Act a 'blueprint' for other sectors.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's like we're in a global subsidy war now, with no clear winners. Gina Raimondo even called the C H I P S Act a 'blueprint' for other sectors.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Regrettably, US Secretary of Commerce Gina Raimondo has recently touted the CHIPS Act as a blueprint for supporting other domestic sectors. Given that other countries will almost certainly respond in kind, it appears that Trumps trade war with China has morphed into a budget-busting global subsidy war that no one can win.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is, uh, kind of alarming when you think about how other nations will retaliate. Remember the trade war with China? This feels like an escalation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is, uh, kind of alarming when you think about how other nations will retaliate. Remember the trade war with China? This feels like an escalation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And studies show subsidies often reduce competition and innovation instead of helping. So why keep pushing them?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And studies show subsidies often reduce competition and innovation instead of helping. So why keep pushing them?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But studies have repeatedly shown that subsidies often harm the countries implementing them. Such measures tend to reduce competition, stifle innovation, raise costs, and disadvantage exporters who rely on imported inputs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Politics, maybe? But economically, it seems like investing in education or infrastructure would give better returns.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Politics, maybe? But economically, it seems like investing in education or infrastructure would give better returns.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Redirecting these funds toward education, job training, research, and infrastructure would do far more to enhance industrial competitiveness, both domestically and globally.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. Instead, we're seeing companies from Europe and Asia setting up shop in the US just to qualify for IRA benefits—so it's distorting investment flows too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. Instead, we're seeing companies from Europe and Asia setting up shop in the U S just to qualify for I R A benefits-so it's distorting investment flows too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Meanwhile, European, Japanese, and South Korean companies are establishing or investing in US facilities to qualify for IRA subsidies and tax credits.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's a messy situation. And honestly, I don't see how this ends well for global trade or consumers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's a messy situation. And honestly, I don't see how this ends well for global trade or consumers.

artist_script:
HostA: Back in 2018, Trump's 25% tariff on steel really set the tone for this new era of protectionism.
HostB: Yeah, and now we're seeing Biden take it even further with things like the Inflation Reduction Act—what, $430 billion?
HostA: Exactly, and the CHIPS Act too, another $280 billion aimed at semiconductors. But it's not just about the money, right? It's how these policies are affecting global trade dynamics.
HostB: Oh, for sure. Like, the EU is already responding with its own $47 billion semiconductor plan. It feels like a subsidy arms race.
HostA: And Morris Chung from TSMC pointed out that manufacturing chips in the US is 50% more expensive than in Taiwan. So these subsidies might not even cover the gap.
HostB: Which makes you wonder, um, if all this spending is actually going to boost competitiveness or just inflate costs for everyone.
HostA: Right, and Adam Posen at the Peterson Institute argues the real cost isn't just trade barriers—it's slower productivity growth in the long run.
HostB: Plus, taxpayers are footing the bill for subsidies that might just get matched by other countries, nullifying any advantage.
HostA: It's like we're in a global subsidy war now, with no clear winners. Gina Raimondo even called the CHIPS Act a "blueprint" for other sectors.
HostB: Which is, uh, kind of alarming when you think about how other nations will retaliate. Remember the trade war with China? This feels like an escalation.
HostA: And studies show subsidies often reduce competition and innovation instead of helping. So why keep pushing them?
HostB: Politics, maybe? But economically, it seems like investing in education or infrastructure would give better returns.
HostA: Totally. Instead, we're seeing companies from Europe and Asia setting up shop in the US just to qualify for IRA benefits—so it's distorting investment flows too.
HostB: Yeah, it's a messy situation. And honestly, I don't see how this ends well for global trade or consumers.
